admreg: Europe and Central Asia,Europe and Central Asia
trustfund:
TF023875-USAID-ENERGY/ENVIRONMENT STUDY
            IN NIS,TF034585-TURKMENISTAN - URBAN TRANSPORT,TF033473-TURKMENISTAN - URBAN TRANSPORT PROJECT,TF032403-TURKMENISTAN - EVALUATION OF
            TRANSPORT ENVIRONMENT (URBAN SECTOR)

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Urban Transport
            Project is rated as unsatisfactory, sustainability as
            unlikely, institutional development impact as negligible,
            Bank performance as unsatisfactory, and Borrower performance
            as unsatisfactory. The project had a discontinued and
            truncated life. Within six months of the loan effectiveness,
            the entire Bank program for Turkmenistan - including the
            project - was suspended for about a year, due to procurement
            irregularities under another Bank operation. The suspension
            was lifted in May 1999. In February 2001, the Government
            requested the Bank to stop the project and cancel the
            remaining balance. The most important lesson from this
            project is that the scope and depth of institutional and
            policy changes have to be well linked to the political
            environment in which it is to be implemented. Secondly, the
            Bank may have erred in estimating the Borrower's
            commitment and surely erred in estimating its capacity for
            change in this project. Thirdly, the Loan/Project Agreements
            only, not the Project Appraisal Document, should define the
            contractual obligations undertaken by the Borrower.
            Fourthly, there was resistance to studies and direct
            technical assistance from external consultants. Fifthly, the
            quality control process may be too quick and too concerned
            with numerical ratings. Finally, the project lacked a
            financial evaluation for major vehicle purchases.
